name: Kepler-387
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-387 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-387 is a star with 1.0220000000000002 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.05 times its radius. It is located 2674.32 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-387 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-387 b

Kepler-387 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.79 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-387.

The mass of Kepler-387 b is 1.04 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-387 b is 1.03 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-387 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-387 c

Kepler-387 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.84 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-387.

The mass of Kepler-387 c is 0.72 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-387 c is 0.89 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-387 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-387, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
